description: Timestamp-to-timestamp story matches between memoir recordings

alternateTellings.topic: Dad, after working as a drayman and policeman, considered farming, especially because he had several teenage sons. A land agent suggested he move to Canada to farm, and eventually, the Achen family, including Lindy, moved from Iowa to Canada, although Lindy doesn’t understand why his dad left the fertile farmland around Sioux City.

Norm_red.preview: My dad had been a drayman and a policeman in a town of 1,200 with 11 barrooms in it. Those were the

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: - be a long drawn-out affair as my memory goes back to the year 1907 when I was a small boy of four

alternateTellings.topic: The Achen family traveled by train from Iowa to Minneapolis, transporting their belongings in a boxcar and the passenger train. Lindy recalls hazy memories of the journey, including the possibility of an overnight stop in Minneapolis.

Norm_red.preview: But along with what they took along, they had a boxcar load of it. And the rest was packed up in the

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: two hours of recording. So as I go along there'll be errors and omissions and there'll be blank spac

alternateTellings.topic: The Achen family traveled by train from Remsen, Iowa to Halbrite, Canada, arriving on March 17th after a winter with heavy snowfall. They stayed in a hotel while livestock and machinery were loaded off the train. Lindy remembers the loading process and the train route, which included stops in Sioux Falls and Sioux City.

Norm_red.preview: And they tell of all the fun they had riding in those side door pullmans, if they call them, along w

alternateTellings.topic: Men from Iowa arrive at the Achen family farm, where they are surprised to find a heavy snowfall that requires them to dig out the barn.

Norm_red.preview: And the boys came up with the livestock, and they had to unload. And take it out to the farm. Now, w

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: This is May the 3rd, 1986. I'm going to make another attempt at re-taping the years of my life. I've

alternateTellings.topic: The Achen family arrives at a farm six miles north of Halbrite. Lindy recalls the house having two bedrooms, a combined dining/living room, and a large kitchen, and remembers it standing for 20-30 years. He also remembers arriving in Halbrite around age four and a half.

Norm_red.preview: We landed in a farm. Six miles north of Halbrite. As I remember it, the house stood there for years

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And I'll try to carry on from here. First off, I'll turn the clock back and sort of reminisce on som

alternateTellings.topic: The Achen family, with twelve children and Lindy (age four and a half) and Liona (age three), lived in a house, and Lindy remembers a time when snow was gone, then reappeared. Later, the family moved from Iowa to Canada, a move Lindy finds perplexing given his father's departure from Sioux City.

Norm_red.preview: And I don't have any recollection of the sleeping arrangements, where we all slept or anything. But

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: - be a long drawn-out affair as my memory goes back to the year 1907 when I was a small boy of four

alternateTellings.topic: When Lindy was about ten years old, his parents took a train trip back to Iowa, and he went with them. The reason for the trip is unclear, and Lindy isn't sure why he was chosen to go.

Norm_red.preview: You knew geography. You've got a good grounding in education. There's no... And writing. They're ver

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: two hours of recording. So as I go along there'll be errors and omissions and there'll be blank spac

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy and his dad traveled, stopping in Minneapolis where his dad took him to a bar offering free food and drinks (whiskey for his dad). Lindy also saw automated newspaper printing machines during the trip, likely at the bar or nearby. They were traveling through Iowa with Lindy’s mother remaining behind.

Norm_red.preview: and took me down with him. And there were all kinds of food. You could have all the food you wanted

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: The horses didn't get hurt. They went - run away wild, over the field. Then we visited through Iowa,

alternateTellings.topic: For several years when Lindy was young, he and his family walked across fields to get to school, a journey that took about two miles. Later, the school moved closer to the main road, only half a mile away.

Norm_red.preview: Oh, no, not any detail, except milking cows and doing chores, and you start doing that when you're e

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: Until I became about eight or nine years old, and then as the farm was expanding, they needed the ho

alternateTellings.topic: When Lindy was 11 years old, he spent the winter at a convent, likely for schooling. He recalls the experience, mentioning it began around November and lasted until Easter time, and he was studying grade five. This visit to the convent is also referenced in Excerpt A, where it is mentioned alongside Lindy’s sister, Sister Aloysia, entering the convent.

Norm_red.preview: As soon as you were old enough to pull weeds, at five and six years old, you're out pulling weeds in

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: Homemade sausage and bread and butter or anything like that. I don't remember any more about the tri

alternateTellings.topic: After finishing grade six around age fourteen, Lindy started grade seven but clashed with his teacher. Feeling dissatisfied, Lindy wanted to quit school and instead help with chores at home, which involved starting a trap line for animals like coyotes, skunks, and weasels. His mother agreed this was a good solution.

Norm_red.preview: I passed my grade six, I would have been about... I must have been fourteen or at least fourteen or

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And it was there that I finished my education, which took me through grade six and into about six we

alternateTellings.topic: Both excerpts discuss Joe and Zip leaving the farm. Excerpt A mentions Joe being in the Army and Zip potentially attending school in Weyburn, while Excerpt B states Joe and Zip both left for the coast in 1921 and 1921-22 respectively, leaving Lindy and Mac to work the farm.

Norm_red.preview: And, now Joe - I think Joe was in the Army at that time. And now, Zip, I don't remember if he went.

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: ... back to many other things besides that, to keep the grain wagons there and whatnot. And as it wa

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy left school to help with farm chores and started trapping animals like coyotes, skunks, and weasels as a side job. He spent his mornings cleaning barns and doing livestock work, and afternoons setting traps.

Norm_red.preview: During that time, well, I was at home and we had a lot of livestock. There's always so much work to

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And between my mother and I, we decided that it was just as well if I stayed home and helped with th

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy’s family receives news about the outside world, specifically the beginning of World War I, through his dad who brings information and newspapers home from trips to town. They were isolated and didn't have a radio until around 1921-1923.

Norm_red.preview: you did it at night by coal or a lamp. And reading wasn't as common as it is today. We had no radio

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: I was taking my grade five, I think. I can remember I couldn't write very good, anyway. And then I r

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy learns that St. Louis, Missouri, offers higher prices for coyote, skunk, and weasel pelts than he's been getting locally. He starts shipping his furs to St. Louis to take advantage of the better prices, and eventually finds a partner, a neighbor boy, to help with the trapping and shipping.

Norm_red.preview: and it was the same thing over and over. And to get back to trapping, after I was trapping for a whi

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And I found a place in St. Louis that was paying exceptionally good prices. So I started nosing arou

alternateTellings.topic: Joe and Zip both leave home to go to the coast, leaving Lindy and Mac to work the farm. Joe leaves in the fall of 1921, and Zip follows during the winter of 1921-22. Bud starts helping out on the farm around this time, as he's growing older.

Norm_red.preview: well, that only lasted so long and then this all happened in about one winter that I was dealing in

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: ... back to many other things besides that, to keep the grain wagons there and whatnot. And as it wa

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy recalls a time when the Achen family worked long hours on their farm, relying on horses for labor. He remembers a particularly difficult winter when heavy snow made it hard to keep the horses on the trail during the journey to the farm, which was six miles north of town.

Norm_red.preview: And we always had to do all the chores. So you worked, worked, and worked. You would work eight, ten

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And then I very vividly remember the ride out to the farm which was six miles north of town. That in

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy, age 13 in the fall of 1915, recalls the construction of a new barn. Workers hauled rock and sand to fill the foundation before a cement layer was applied. Later, Lindy slept in the haymow of the barn, using a horse blanket and straw for a pillow while sleeping on the hard floor, and was awakened by the boss.

Norm_red.preview: he put down the foundation everything then we had to haul all those rock in to fill that foundation

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: But sleeping in a haymow with a horse blanket was the only covers that you got. So I used to take my

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy and his brother Mac started working at a young age, helping the Achen family build a pasture around 1914. They were taken a mile and a half away to dig post holes, and Lindy quickly became a top hole-digger, outperforming older workers due to his strength. He worked on the job for about a month, impressing the boss with his productivity.

Norm_red.preview: I don't remember the detail. But that gives you an idea of how hard we worked when we were young. I

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: So he got me a sharp bar. The third day I was able to dig as many holes as anybody on the gang. And

alternateTellings.topic: Both excerpts describe difficult years for Lindy and his family on their farm. Excerpt A details the hard work and short crops from 1914-1918, specifically mentioning Lindy's role hauling bundles at age 15 and becoming too tired to finish. Excerpt B focuses on the particularly harsh drought of 1918 and the family's struggle to find enough feed and seed, managing to survive without government assistance. They both highlight a period of hardship and labor for Lindy and his family.

Norm_red.preview: through the 1914, '15, '16, it was the same thing. It was a repetitious thing. And short on help. I

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: It would only pull about as much as five horses, I'd say. About equivalent to a five-horse load. Tha

alternateTellings.topic: Dad bought a Titan tractor, initially around 1918 and later referenced in 1921 when the Achen family harvested a low-grade wheat crop. Lindy recalls the tractor's slow speed, less than three miles per hour, and its equivalent power to six horses. The purchase occurred during the 1917-1918 flu pandemic, which particularly impacted pregnant women.

Norm_red.preview: In 1921, then, we got a crop. And Dad bought a... Oh, in the meantime, 1918, he had bought a little

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: Fortunately, there wasn't anybody in our neighborhood that died from it, but there were an awful lot

alternateTellings.topic: that results in Lindy, at age 19, being put in charge of the farm operation. Excerpt B describes a winter in 1923 when Lindy’s mother and Leona went to California, and Lindy and his father hauled grain with wagons instead of sleighs due to the mild weather.

Norm_red.preview: It went about 20 bushels per acre, but a low grade of wheat. Dad bought a small separator for that t

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And time went fast, you worked hard, you were tired when night come, you were satisfied to bed and c

alternateTellings.topic: The Achen family experienced good harvests in 1922 and 1923, which meant constant work on the farm. Lindy ran a thrashing outfit during this time and helped with the harvest. Life was filled with chores but occasionally included schoolhouse dances, card games with neighbors, and reading by lamplight. The good fortune ended in 1924 when the crop was poor, and Lindy's dad died in the spring.

Norm_red.preview: So I was the chief cook and bottle washer around the thrashing machine. I was running the thrashing

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And in '23, we were having good crops, '22, '23. And it was just work work work all the time. That's

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy, 22 years old in 1924, got a job running a thrashing outfit in Griffin. Shortly after starting the job, the machine malfunctioned. A cog fell out, damaged the blower, and caused significant damage – the blower required 20 horsepower to operate.

Norm_red.preview: We were through harvesting real early. And, oh yes, in '24, in '24, yeah, we had finished. And then

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: It hadn't run for five minutes, and all of a sudden, bang-a-dee-bang, the pieces started flying arou

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy prepares a thrasher for operation. Initially, he expected it to run smoothly all day and was confident in his ability to lace the belts correctly. When he returns for a trial run on Saturday, a hired worker doesn't show up, so Lindy and Martin Twight have to prepare the machine themselves, which involves attaching the belts to the steam engine.

Norm_red.preview: Oh, I could tell you the incidental experiences that I had on those thrashing outfits when I got aro

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And we're going to make a trial run on Saturday. So you come on back over on Saturday and we'll just

alternateTellings.topic: Both excerpts describe the death of Lindy's dad in 1924. Excerpt A focuses on Bud’s role on the farm after the death, noting Bud was 13 at the time and helping fill his dad's shoes while still attending school. Excerpt B details the funeral itself – it was a large, rainy event where Dad’s body was brought to the farm before being transported to town for burial, with people traveling by horse-drawn carriages.

Norm_red.preview: Unless you thrashed, it would be very difficult for you to understand what I'm talking about. That w

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: Right now, I'll go back now to about 1924, yes. Dad was dead and buried. Big funeral; rainy day; dro

alternateTellings.topic: Both excerpts discuss the Achen family’s time in Halbrite. Excerpt A focuses on the education of Mac, Zip, and Leona, while Excerpt B describes Lindy’s early memories of arriving in Halbrite at age four and a half and starting school around age seven.

Norm_red.preview: Mac dropped out of school about grade seven, I'd say. Now, that's the farthest that he went to schoo

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And I'll try to carry on from here. First off, I'll turn the clock back and sort of reminisce on som

alternateTellings.topic: The Achen family arrives in Halbrite, Saskatchewan, in March. They stay in a hotel while livestock and machinery are loaded, and Lindy remembers this vividly. Lindy later reflects on the education levels achieved by family members, including Leona who attended school in Halbrite and then moved to California.

Norm_red.preview: And Leona got her grade nine, I think, and grade eight in the convent. And then she went to high sch

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: The idea was for each one of them to get a quarter section of land and become a farmer, which was a

alternateTellings.topic: Both excerpts describe Lindy’s time in Halbrite. Excerpt A focuses on the routine of attending Mass and summer picnics, while Excerpt B recalls arriving in Halbrite around the age of four and a half and starting school around age seven. Both recall Halbrite as a significant place in Lindy's early life.

Norm_red.preview: Every other Sunday, we went to Mass in Halbrite. That took two or three hours out of the center of t

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And I'll try to carry on from here. First off, I'll turn the clock back and sort of reminisce on som

alternateTellings.topic: Following his father's death in 1924, the Achen family held a large funeral. Dad's body was initially brought to the farm and remained there for a couple of days before being transported to town for the service, which was held on a rainy day and required attendees to use horse-drawn carriages due to difficult road conditions. Lindy's mother had previously left for California in the fall of 1923, leaving Leona to manage the household.

alternateTellings.topic: In the fall of 1923, Lindy’s mother and Leona traveled to California while Lindy and his dad hauled grain with wagons. The winter that year was mild, so they didn’t need to use sleighs.

Norm_red.preview: There I mentioned that our crop was fair and that Dad had died that year. And I'll go back and tell

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And time went fast, you worked hard, you were tired when night come, you were satisfied to bed and c

alternateTellings.topic: Following his father’s death, his body was brought to the Achen family farm and remained there for a couple of days before a large funeral was held in Halbrite. Lindy's mother traveled by train from Portland to attend. Lindy then took charge of the farm in 1924.

Norm_red.preview: So we got a hold of her there, and I went back home. We had the body shipped back to Halbrite for bu

alternateTellings.topic: Both excerpts describe Lindy's mother and Leona traveling to California, likely for the winter. In 1924, Lindy and Mac ran the farm, with Bud and Leona also present, but Leona went to California. The winter of 1923 was mild, and Lindy and his dad hauled grain with wagons instead of sleighs.

Norm_red.preview: mother,  mother got there by train it's funny how you could move around in those days. She'd come al

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy was working on the farm when relatives from California questioned his wages, which were $1,000 for one year and planned to be $1,200 the next. Lindy argued that if they thought the wages were too high, he would leave. He then packed a suitcase and left with his cousin Norbert Hemmer, traveling to Iowa (specifically Worthington) to help with the harvest.

Norm_red.preview: '26, some of the boys came up from California, and they thought Mother was paying me too much money.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy visits relatives in Iowa and gets a temporary job helping a blacksmith, where he trims horses' feet while the blacksmith puts on shoes.

Norm_red.preview: I had a few hundred dollars in my pocket. I got down to Iowa to where I had a lot of relatives. I'd

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: two hours of recording. So as I go along there'll be errors and omissions and there'll be blank spac

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy asked for a job after hearing the boss was firing someone. He was hired and started working for 35 cents an hour, earning $3.50 a day, and paying $1 a day for room and board. He quickly became a very productive worker, digging more holes than anyone else.

Norm_red.preview: I dug as many holes as anybody the fourth day, and the fifth day I dug more holes than anybody, and

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: I heard the boss say to another man, he's going to fire him tonight." So I went to the boss and I sa

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy decides to quit his job because the work requires a lot of travel and he wants to settle down. This decision happens after Joe and Zip leave to go to the coast, leaving Lindy and Mac to work the farm alone.

Norm_red.preview: So I said, "I'll quit my job, and I'll come up and I'll put your crop in for you," I said. When I we

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: ... back to many other things besides that, to keep the grain wagons there and whatnot. And as it wa

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy, age 25, takes over his brother’s farm, which raises corn, cattle, and hogs. The farm is located six miles north of a small town in Canada, and the family arrives by train, with livestock and machinery loaded onto rail cars. Lindy recalls a particularly snowy winter during this time.

alternateTellings.topic: A hailstorm flattened 40 acres of oats belonging to a farmer named Lorry. Lindy suggested calling the neighbors, and together they spent several days stacking the flattened oats into piles.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy helped his neighbors thrash their harvested grain. He hauled bundles on the equipment and got frustrated when the operator wouldn’t move the machine, leading to a dusty day of work. This happened during a period when the Achen family had good crops in 1922 and 1923, alongside a lot of general farm work and occasional social events like dances and card games with neighbors.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy leaves a job and travels north, visiting his brother in Sioux Falls and then heading to Aberdeen, South Dakota, to see his uncle. Both excerpts mention Lindy’s uncle living near Aberdeen and Lindy’s travels in the area. Excerpt B adds details about a previous heatwave and a stop at Lorry's place before Aberdeen.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy earned $300 from a previous job and used the money to drive his Model T Ford to Canada to visit family. He spent a couple of weeks there before returning home in the fall. The trip occurred after a week-long heatwave, and Lindy stopped by Lorry's place before continuing on to Aberdeen, South Dakota.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy is looking for work and asks the boss for a job after hearing about a firing. The boss agrees and puts Lindy on a boring machine to help with a project that needs to run 24 hours a day, based on a recommendation from the timekeeper.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy received an offer from a man in South Dakota, Martin Twight, to run his separator for $12 a day. He left his current job to take the position and worked for Twight’s outfit for 30 days straight, including Sundays, averaging 12 hours a day.

alternateTellings.topic: After moving from Iowa to Canada with his large family, Lindy drove north and stopped to talk to a line gang foreman. He told the foreman about his background.

alternateTellings.topic: The Achen family moves from Iowa to Canada. Lindy recalls this move years later, wondering why his father left the farmland in Iowa. Later, Lindy plans to return to Canada and considers renting the family farm with his brother Mac, as his mother and brother Bud want to leave the farm.

alternateTellings.topic: In 1924, Lindy started running the Achen family farm alongside Mac. It was a dry year, resulting in a smaller crop. Lindy's mother paid him $600 per year and let him use the car.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy expresses a desire to learn new skills and tells his boss he can build more holes than anyone else. As a result, Lindy and the crew move to Winnebago, Nebraska, where Lindy’s boss promises to teach him other skills. Shortly after, the foreman recognizes Lindy’s building expertise and considers making him foreman, but is conflicted because he'd previously promised the position to Jack.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy temporarily takes a job to earn money, intending to return to farming. He discusses this with a foreman named John, who agrees to let him work temporarily. This arrangement is influenced by a prior disagreement between Lindy's dad, Joe, and Zip, which led to Lindy being assigned to operate a new separator and tractor on the farm in the fall of 1921.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy expresses a desire to learn new skills and is offered a position in service work by a superintendent. He's initially unfamiliar with tasks like meter reading, but the superintendent offers to train him. This leads to a move with the crew to Winnebago, Nebraska, where he’ll learn those new skills.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy works a winter job servicing meters and customers, planning to return home in March. Around the 17th of March, the Achen family arrives in Halbrite, stays in a hotel, and loads livestock and machinery while Lindy anticipates returning to the farm at the end of March.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy travels to Regina, Saskatchewan, initially to take a telephone course in the winter of 1922 to learn how to maintain rural telephones. Later, he considers contacting the Power Commission and receives advice about government takeover, and he visits a schoolteacher in the countryside while out of town.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy travels to Midale, where Mac is living, to discuss installing a power plant distribution system. Lindy requests a month in Iowa with his mother before beginning the work.

alternateTellings.topic: After Joe and Zip leave for the coast, Lindy and his brother Mac work on the farm alone through 1921 and 1922. As the work finishes, Lindy travels to Regina in May to seek employment with the power commission, but he's turned away because they are laying off workers.

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy applies for a job at a work site, but the superintendent criticizes him for seeking work both in the winter and summer. He’s ultimately told they aren't hiring. Shortly after, Lindy successfully secures a job at 35 cents an hour, starting on January 4th, 1927.

Norm_red.preview: See if I can get a job. "Get a job? We're still laying off men. Things are that tough that we're sti

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: I heard the boss say to another man, he's going to fire him tonight." So I went to the boss and I sa

alternateTellings.topic: Both excerpts describe a poor harvest on the Achen family farm. Lindy was helping with chores alongside Bud and his cousin Tad, while Joe and Zip left for the coast, leaving Lindy and Mac to work the farm alone. Bud was starting to become more helpful on the farm at that time.

Norm_red.preview: Well, he'll never know how close I come to climbing over his desk and punching him in the nose, but

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: ... back to many other things besides that, to keep the grain wagons there and whatnot. And as it wa

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy, age 19, starts operating a newly acquired separator and tractor for the Achen family in the fall of 1921. An argument between Lindy’s dad, Joe, and Zip resulted in Lindy being assigned the task. He runs both the separator and the engine, earning a small wage while Bud, who hired him, makes more money from the operation.

Norm_red.preview: We put our little thrashing outfit to work, and we got the harvests off of them. There were others a

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And then it was the fall of '21. Dad bought a little separator to go with the little Titan tractor w

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy travels to a town that lacks wiring and power. He and his brother Mac are tasked with wiring the buildings, while a contractor builds the power lines. The timeframe includes June, with Mac joining about two weeks later. This work seems connected to Lorry’s business, and Lindy spends April, May, June, and part of July working for him.

Norm_red.preview: There's no wiring in the town. There isn't a power of any kind in the town. There's about 120 places

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: get by with what we have to have in a good home." Well, he said, "I'll tell you something. You'll le

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy worked for Martin Twight, running a separator machine for 30 days straight, including Sundays, and working an average of 12 hours a day. This work coincided with a period when Lindy was frequently on call and Dominion Electric was expanding operations in the Peace River country.

Norm_red.preview: And there's '41, '42, '43, '44, on call, 24 hours a day, 30 days a month. But when I got holidays -

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: "A kid like you run Martin Twight's outfit - separator?" I said, "Yes." "Oh," he said, "You're too y

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy trains young, inexperienced workers. He motivates them with a mix of encouragement and reprimands, fostering loyalty. He wakes them up early, around 4:45 AM, using the phrase "Daylight in the swamp," so they can start the machines running by 6:00 AM.

Norm_red.preview: You know, young guys, 18 years old. They knew nothing from nothing, and you train them. But I saw th

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: and his way of calling was, "Daylight in the swamp, boys; daylight in the swamp." Well, after laying

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy trains new employees by having them dig anchor holes, initially instructing them with shovels. He demonstrates how to use the tools and expects them to work hard, ultimately "hardening" them. Later, Lindy himself becomes a top hole-digger on a crew, outperforming older workers due to his strength and youth, and earning recognition from the boss.

Norm_red.preview: You'd have to let him go. There was an awful lot of shovel work in those days. You'd break a guy in

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: So he got me a sharp bar. The third day I was able to dig as many holes as anybody on the gang. And

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy provided equipment rental services for a city power project. He initially struggled with a dull digging tool, which an older crew member helped him remedy by providing a sharper one. Lindy's job involved billing every two weeks and receiving a commission, making it a steady income source.

Norm_red.preview: Not a big crew. A crew about six men. mostly. Five, six men, boring machine, pole truck, and another

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: I got ahold of a bar for digging through frost that was just so dull. And I went out and I thought t

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy traveled to Regina to take a telephone maintenance course, which kept him away from his family for six weeks. Phyllis expressed concern about his absence, as they had multiple young children at home, but Lindy felt obligated to continue working.

Norm_red.preview: There was one time that I didn't get home for six weeks. Phyllis was in Regina here with the kids. W

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: I heard my first radio, I think it was 1921. Maybe later than that, it could have been '22 or '23, I

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy and his crew were working in the Ogema-Shanavan area in 1950-1951, constructing power lines. They started work very early, around 4:40 or 4:45 AM, with the boss waking them with the phrase "Daylight in the swamp." The team needed to have the machinery running by 6:00 AM.

Norm_red.preview: And then down in the Ogema-Shanavan area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: and his way of calling was, "Daylight in the swamp, boys; daylight in the swamp." Well, after laying

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy started a business doing foundation piling as a way to keep his crew employed when other work was scarce. He began by digging holes, which were difficult because the ground was frozen solid. As the new man on the crew, Lindy was given the least desirable tools, a dull bar for digging through the frozen ground.

Norm_red.preview: And so when the work was all let out, I was sitting there, I didn't have any work. I said, "Well, we

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: This was on January the 4th, 1927. I'll always remember that date. My first day was digging holes. T

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy's company was building many farms and needed to maintain multiple machines, including one specifically designed for deep foundation boring. Lindy personally worked long hours preparing the machines each night and ensuring they didn’t stop, dealing with equipment problems like an engine governor issue and a brief shutdown of a separator.

Norm_red.preview: When we were building 500 farms a year, we had to have two machines going steady in the country and

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And I want to tell you that every night I worked until midnight, lacing belts and getting everything

alternateTellings.topic: Both excerpts discuss George Jenney's decision to sell his land near Assiniboia, Saskatchewan, after paying it off after 20 years of work. Excerpt A focuses specifically on George's retirement and sale of shares, while Excerpt B implies George's land acquisition was part of a larger family move to Canada to acquire cheap land on the prairie.

Norm_red.preview: And I'm sure he didn't, because when electricity hits you, you don't know what hits you. Then the ne

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: Whatever possessed my dad to leave that rich farmland down around Sioux City, Iowa, and move up into

alternateTellings.topic: After Lindy's initial two-year apprenticeship ended, his employer put him on a retainer because he held an electrician's license, which was required for certain jobs. Although he rarely went on these jobs, his presence fulfilled a requirement for inspections.

Norm_red.preview: And they pay their rent every month on the dot, and they still - Oh, yes, after my two years was up,

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: I see that you're doing more work than any of these other fellows, but you -" He said, "But you didn

alternateTellings.topic: After Dad died, Lindy, at 21, took over running the family farm, drawing on his experience with machinery and managing people, which he’d learned from his father. He was responsible for hiring and firing workers and making planting decisions, continuing the farm operations.

Norm_red.preview: And having my background and experience is what carried me through. It was - I knew a lot about mach

alternateTellings.topic: Both excerpts recount the time following Dad's death. Excerpt B describes the funeral itself – it was a large, rainy affair where Dad’s body was brought to the farm before being moved for burial. Excerpt A picks up the story three years later, when Lindy began working in the power business and quickly took on leadership roles, emphasizing the importance of managing employees.

Norm_red.preview: After Dad died, when I was 21 years old, three years I spent there. Then when I started in the power

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy explains his job history to someone, mentioning he worked at Iowa Electric for four months before moving on to South Dakota. He also mentions that the Achen family left Iowa when he was a boy.

Norm_red.preview: He brought it up to me then. "Well," he said, "You've got a history of jumping around a lot." "Well,

alternateTellings.topic: An employee wanted to quit his job, and Lindy was tasked with getting a release slip from unemployment insurance for him, a requirement during wartime. Lindy later tells his boss about this encounter and announces his own intention to quit at the end of the week, expressing a preference for a more stable life.

Norm_red.preview: I said, every time you leave town, he comes in and says, He wants to quit. "Where's the superintende

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy's team bought a Williams boring machine from Billings, Montana, which initially could only bore 18 feet deep. Lindy and his team then modified the machine in their shop to extend its depth to 30 feet, requiring extensive preparation and maintenance, including working until midnight each night to keep it running.

Norm_red.preview: We bought a Williams boring machine from Billings, Montana, and it would only go down 18 feet. And w

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And I want to tell you that every night I worked until midnight, lacing belts and getting everything

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy arranged for Art to buy a drilling machine in Billings, Montana. The machine initially only drilled 20 feet, so Lindy and his team modified it to drill 32 feet. Later, Lindy prepared the machine for a test run, but a worker didn’t show up, so he and Martin Twight harnessed the steam engine to the machine to test it.

Norm_red.preview: I may have said this earlier on the tape. I'd tell about buying the machine down at Billings, Montan

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And we're going to make a trial run on Saturday. So you come on back over on Saturday and we'll just

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy buys a used boring machine to help with his company's work. He initially prepares for a test run on a Saturday but the hired worker doesn’t show up, so Lindy and Martin Twight work together to harness the steam engine to the machine using belts. Later, Lindy’s machine proves to be exceptionally efficient, digging more footage than a competitor had in a decade, despite him refusing to share the secrets to its success.

Norm_red.preview: We would take them in and find their weakness. the city had one, ten years old and they had it in th

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And we're going to make a trial run on Saturday. So you come on back over on Saturday and we'll just

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy buys some old, failing machines from a competitor, who later goes out of business. Lindy and his team repair the machines, and Lindy uses them successfully for ten years. A later conversation indicates Lindy was considering buying a machine from Martin Twight that had recently been overhauled.

Norm_red.preview: And I wouldn't have defied anybody to dig a hole with either one of those machines. And the guy said

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: "From morning 'til night. We bet that we wouldn't have any trouble during the day." However, I went

alternateTellings.topic: A trenching machine malfunctions shortly after starting up. A cog falls out and damages the blower, which requires 20 horsepower. Lindy's company contrasts their productivity with companies like Power Corporation, who had multiple stalls but weren't efficient and would often request urgent repairs on machinery like the malfunctioning trenching machine.

Norm_red.preview: That's the biggest thing. I've seen these shops, you know, with five or six stalls in them. The Powe

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: It hadn't run for five minutes, and all of a sudden, bang-a-dee-bang, the pieces started flying arou

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy’s boss recognized he was outperforming his colleagues despite lacking seniority. The boss intervened and ensured Lindy would be paid 40 cents an hour. Afterward, the boss asked Lindy to move with them across the state.

Norm_red.preview: And I said, "It can't be anything else." They were looking in the substation. I was looking in the s

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: I see that you're doing more work than any of these other fellows, but you -" He said, "But you didn

alternateTellings.topic: After an argument between Lindy’s dad (Joe) and Zip, 19-year-old Lindy was put in charge of operating a new separator and tractor on the Achen family farm in the fall of 1921. Lindy considered himself lucky to have been given this responsibility at a young age, and it was part of a process of gaining authority in his work.

Norm_red.preview: the main thing is that you're always bettering your own position. Use the old saying, day by day, in

TDK_D60_edited_through_air.preview: And then it was the fall of '21. Dad bought a little separator to go with the little Titan tractor w

alternateTellings.topic: Lindy took over running the Achen family farm at age 19, following his father’s death when Lindy was 21. He managed the farm's operations, finances, and planting decisions, continuing the practices he learned from his dad. His mother and brothers, Mac and Bud, were also left on the farm.

Norm_red.preview: And the fact that when I was home, I was put in charge of things from the time I was 19 years old. M
